text: In order to understand the role of NF-kappaB in EBV transformation we have established stably transfected <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> into lymphoblastoid cells .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_0> Gene_expression stably transfected <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Theme IkappaBalpha <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Positive_regulation stably transfected <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Theme stably transfected <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1>

text: Two clones were obtained in which the loss of NF-kappaB binding activity correlated with the constitutive expression of the transgenic <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Protein latency expression was determined by immunocytochemistry .
Expression of surface markers , intracytoplasmic content of cytokines cell cycle analysis after BrdU incorporation and DNA staining with propidium iodide were studied by flow cytometry .
Percentage of apoptotic cells was determined by in-situ labelling of DNA strand breaks .
No significative changes in EBV latency nor in cell surface marker expression was found .
In contrast , intracytoplasmic <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> levels were strongly reduced in transfected clones .
Furthermore , 30 % of <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transfected cells were apoptotic after 8 h of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_0> Gene_expression transfected <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Theme IkappaBalpha <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Positive_regulation transfected <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Theme transfected <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1>

text: This correlated with a strong reduction of BrdU incorporation after 24 h of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment .
No effect was seen with non transfected cells or with cells transfected with a control plasmid .

Our results suggest that the <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene could be one of the targets of NF-kappaB in EBV infected cells and that NF-kappaB protects EBV-infected cells from apoptosis induced by <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which may favour the proliferative effect of this cytokine .
